comments.commentBody:
I wrote as clearly as I could under the 1500 character constraint.
Basically, create a tax incentive to manufacture excess inventory.
Businesses will hire workers to build inventory in extended shifts.
The extended shifts results in greater capital infrastructure use at minimum cost thus lowering the unit cost of all units in the extended inventory.
Lower prices will spur sales and demand just like a sale.
People will be working, more sales will occur, businesses make more money and pay more taxes, sales taxes increase helping local governments. Products will be more competitive in the world markets.
This is simply better than simple hiring tax incentives without jobs purposes.
Private investors could realize a fine return on investment in excess inventory when it sells, roughly equal to the profit margin.
This would create sustainable demand with self perpetuating efficiency improvements leading to further capital expenditures for buildings and equipment etc.
You must create demand, here and abroad.
A company makes more money when it can operate three shifts a day instead of one or two.
Both parties can agree on this pro-business proposal.
Awesome idea commissar! How many widgets do the planners in Washington say to make? I'll get the workers right on it!  A new five year plan to build America and make her strong!

There is only so much the Fed can do to keep the cost of money low.  This slowly enables refinancing, deleveraging and asset optimization.  If we really want to kick off growth, we need to end the tax cuts and plow that money into large scale infrastructure, R&D and education investments.  Focus on impact rather than spreading money around.  Then businesses will feel compelled to put their money to work.
We have more deadbeats than 20 yrs ago.
The new bubble is a war bubble silly! lots of profits to be made in the defense industry. I hoping for a war in Iran next. Can't wait!

"While the Fed hates being held hostage to market expectations, we doubt it will be prepared to disappoint global investors this week.": Lou Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson ICAP (?).  This sounds like the expectations of consumers buying into a bubble, whether the hisorical Dutch tulip bubble or the recent American real estate bubble.  Is the stock market in a bubble?

Let the markets collapse Mr bernanke.  It will happen anyway and the longer you kick the can down the road, the worse it will get.  A real stimulus would be for the Obama administration to cut the deficit and let corporate America spend money without worrying higher taxes will be required to fund the welfare spending

Yes, nothing like a little serotonin syndrome for the economy, if you don't mind a medical analogy. I can't wait to see the coming convulsions. Bank runs will be fun, but I'm excited about mass hysteria, grocery runs, and a good old fashioned crack up boom. Black markets are like farmer's markets, but for stuff you actually can't get anywhere else! I think I'll buy a new wheelbarrow. What will I need a wallet for?

Time to admit our economy depends on people spending

wildly beyond their means. At one point Democrats (George McGovern?)

proposed a guaranteed government minimum income for everyone.

Ben should just start writing everyone a check to buy multiple luxury SUVs,

McMansions, vacation homes, etc, in short, the minimum lifestyle

all Americans are entitled to as birthright - you could argue people

should earn these things, but hey, isn't shopping hard work ??

And as Paul Krugman argues, spending is a selfless patriotic act,

where one person's spending creates another's job.

So Ben, fire up the printing presses and helicopter drop that cash !!

"...Obama needs to start creating jobs on his own as FDR did."

why don't _you_ start creating some jobs? i am sure that Mr. Obama already has a busy schedule.

just do it!
Kinda late for that.  Obama should have done that 3 yrs ago at the latest.  Instead he tried to be palsy with his sworn enemies.

Dr. Krugman won a Nobel Prize for a reason..so why doesn't our government listen to him?

We desperately need much more stimulus money! Two trillion! We have soldiers coming home from Iraq and Afghanistan who will need jobs. We can't depend on a standing army to hire any more. We have 50% of current college graduates without jobs and facing crushing debt...those who didn't "borrow from mommy and daddy!"

This is the time to build infrastructure that is failing badly across these fifty states. Construction materials are at an all-time low price and we have laborers ready to work. Let's do it before winter snow impedes progress.

We need to get cracking on alternative energy plants and turbines because if by some horrific turn of events and Romney gets in we will NEVER see anything but drill baby drill.

We need money to rehire teachers, police and fireman...before the regressive Republicans defund public schools and privatize all first responders and prisons.

Every poll says the same thing over and over. It's the economy stupid! Not abortion, not birth control, and not immigration. Jobs, jobs, jobs! Not repeal of an already compromised affordable health care act!

If the Romney-Ryan budget passes in the USA we can permanently say goodbye to any middle class...that is if any are left.

Right now instead of campaigning, Obama needs to start creating jobs on his own as FDR did. No more reaching across the aisle. JUST DO IT!
The only person that the "Mayor for Life" would like to endorse is himself. That's what paternalistic megalomaniacs do!

Wait a week. Bishop Etch-a-Sketch will cave to the poll tested position.
We can expect nothing less from the cowardly bully, Bishop Willard, prep school cheerleader, VietNam draft dodger Romney.
You put your drivel here yourself.
I am so glad I'm not a politician. Who wants to have their casual conversation at a party turn up in the New York Times?

What exactly is the value of a Bloomberg endorsement? I am dismayed that Obama continues to court him. If Bloomberg did not endorse Obama in 2008 and reportedly called the president "the most arrogant person he's ever met", then it's pretty obvious Bloomberg would never endorse Obama.

This is not a surprise.
Other than a few opinion writers for the NYT, who cares what Michael Bloomberg thinks  of the candidates?

My assumption is his Bloomberg's views on Romney, are based on Romney's personal (more moderate) viewpoints, and not on his (ultra-conservative) positions as a Republican Candidate for President in 2012. That, and his leadership/policies as Massachusetts Governor.

Bloomberg does not think Romney will be anywhere near as extreme as his positions in the 2012 Primary suggest. He also sees Obama not having got his agenda through Congress, and speculates on whether Romney with his business background and corporate support could usher in these bold economic policies Obama hasn't been able to.
Nah, it's just the Times trying to sabotage the Romney campaign.

If he's Bloomberg's pick, I may have to re-think supporting Romney.

On the other hand, ABO 2012
this is not actually all that flattering for Romney.  a cabbage, or a pickle, any sentient being or non-sentient thing would be better than Obama
He must have been Coked up.

To those who mention Romney's wealth and assume he is somehow some kind of elitist snob, you better hope that ABC, NBC and CBS continue with that mantra til election day.. because when you compare lifestyles, the Romneys, with all their wealth, act much less elite than the Obamas.

Have you heard about Romney tying his poor old dog to the top of the station wagon for a family vacation in his little doggy carrier?

Have you tried to fit your family of seven in the car for a family trip?

Can you envision the Obamas in a station wagon? Driving on a family trip? me neither.

Face it. Romney is much more down to earth. He gives boatloads to charity, too.

I'm with Bloomberg...Romney will do a better job running the country and is more in touch with the common man.
Well, if Moron Bloomberg is going to ban anything he should ban Obama votes!
I sure wouldn't want you running it.
Christ, my crazy next door neighbor would be better at running the country than Obama.
Gee Mike, ya think? Obama has been a 100% disaster for the country. And FYI Florida is not a toss up, it is leaning Romney, thank God.

If Democrats are not playing a class-card, they are playing a race card. Bloomberg knows quite well that we are dealing with an incompetent community agitator and not a president of all the people. He knows full well that Obama is bad for the economy, bad for the necessary task of leadership on contentious issues and clearly dangerous for the U.S. economy and the chance for recovery. Every number proves just how bad for America he is yet, Bloomberg does not have the courage to commit to anything beyond America's waist line. He admits his concern for social issues but, where is his concern for the number one issue, the economy? We each have to make a decision, this country depends on it. Bloomberg says he is perhaps willing to accept second best.  Bloomberg is part of the problem not the solution because if we do not choose the best government we can, we get the government we deserve.

With 600,000 or so Millionaires living in New York City - most of them Liberal Democrats - you can bet they are worried about who's in office. The USA can only survive for so long living on billions of new debt every day. Just remember people, it costs the Treasury about $250 to print up $1million in $100 dollar bills. The catch is, it's based on nothing and YOU get to pay back the $1 million that only cost a few hundred to make. At least Romney is ethical, unless you disprove of good ethics?

Yeah, and if Mr. Soda said it, it must be true.

Please give me a break!

Mr Bloomberg's policies should give you some idea of what a Mitt presidency would be like.
Eat cake
